DOC.HEAD: Slowed to 0.4 Percent in November
Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT grammar. SUBS last graf to clarify that the figures are not for all of 1989.
DOC.TEXT: Consumer prices in the 12 European Community nations rose by an average of 0.4 percent in November, slowing from a 0.6 percent increase in October, the economic bloc said Thursday. Its statistical bureau said EC inflation would be about 5.5 percent for 1989, up from 4.4 percent in 1988 and 3.4 percent in 1987. The highest price increases in November were in Portugal, with 1 percent, and in Britain and Greece, with 0.9 percent each. Prices were unchanged in the Netherlands, while the consumer price index fell 0.1 percent in Belgium. The EC said rates of inflation for the 12 European countries so far in 1989 were as follows: Greece, 14 percent; Portugal, 11.5 percent; Britain, 7.5 percent; Spain, 7.0 percent; Italy, 6.0 percent; Denmark, 4.8 percent; Ireland, 4.7 percent; Luxembourg, 3.8 percent; France, 3.5 percent; Belgium, 3.3 percent; West Germany, 3.0 percent; Netherlands, 1.2 percent.
